Yeah understood, Most people use a database to store the refresh token and portal id, so in your case your flow would look like this:
User installs your app,
You store the refresh token in the database along with the portalid,
Using webhooks you watch for changes to the property that you're talking about.
Whenever one of those changes happens you use the portalid in the webhook to lookup the refresh token for that portal,
You use the refresh token to make the api call to update the property>
If the refresh token ever needs to be refreshed you just refresh it and store the new one in the database

Well that's an app that probably doesn't have a HubSpot plug in it's probably just a chrome extension (I definitely could be wrong though). The issue that most people face is that HubSpot has limited options on where you can add things to the UI so most people resort to using chrome extensions
CRM cards are definitely the preferred option for HubSpot though (but these only work on CRM detail pages not listing pages)
You can have installs without it being listed (actually you need 3 installs before it can be listed)
